docs.title: What is Steev?
docs.text:
Steev is an AI-powered training assistant that revolutionizes your AI training workflow:

✨ Zero Configuration Required ✨ Automated Management ✨ Enhanced Performance

Whether you’re working with LLMs, computer vision, or any deep learning models, Steev streamlines your workflow and maximizes productivity.

docs.title: 🤝 Review with Your Engineering Buddy
docs.text: Think of Steev as your always-available colleague. Through natural conversation, Steev helps you easily manage your training process.

docs.title: 🚀 24/7 Babysitter for Your Training
docs.text:
No more babysitting your training process. Steev provides intelligent guidance and support by:

  • Continuous monitoring the training process
  • Proactively detecting anomalies

docs.title: 📊 Real-Time Monitoring & Notifications
docs.text:
Keep track of what matters:

  • Model metrics (loss, accuracy)
  • Training progress
  • Convergence patterns

Instant alerts when your attention is needed - no more constant checking!

Run your training process with Steev and forget about it. Steev will take care of the rest.

docs.title: Installation Guide
docs.text: This guide will help you install Steev on your system.

docs.title: System Requirements
docs.text:
• Python 3.11 or higher
  • Packages to execute your training code (e.g. transformers, unsloth)

docs.title: Installation Steps
docs.text: Note that we’ve tested only on Linux. MacOS and Windows are not supported yet.

docs.title: Using pip
docs.text:
The easiest way to install Steev is using pip:

pip install steev

docs.title: Verifying Installation
docs.text:
To verify that Steev is installed correctly:

steev version

Expected output

steev version 0.1.0

docs.title: Sign-up / Login
docs.text:
After installation, you need to sign-up or login to your account.

steev auth login

If you are using a remote server, it means no-browser login is required. You can use the auth token to login.

Expected output

Choose authentication method:
  Log in with web browser(Login from local)
  Paste an auth token(Login from remote server)

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text: Now that you have Steev installed, check out the Quick Tour to get started!

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
After you have installed Steev, you can start using it by running the following command:

steev run train.py

If you have previously used additional arguments to edit parameters, you can use the same arguments to run Steev.

steev run train.py --kwargs learning-rate=0.001 batch-size=32
# Or, steev run train.py --kwargs lr=0.001 bs=32

docs.title: What Happens Next?
docs.text:
When you run this command, Steev will:

  1. Review Your Code

    • Analyze architecture & dataset
    • Check configurations
    • Suggest improvements

  2. Monitor Training and Proactively Respond

    • Track metrics
    • Detect anomalies
    • Manage resources

  3. Optimize & Deliver

    • Fine-tune parameters
    • Select best weights
    • Generate reports

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
Ready to dive deeper? Here’s what you can do next:

  1. 📚 Read our Installation Guide
  2. 💡 Try the Tutorials
  3. 👥 Join our Discord Community
  4. 🔧 Explore Commands

docs.title: steev config file
docs.text: steev config file is a yaml file that contains the configuration for the analysis.

docs.title: 📚 Tutorials
docs.text: To Be Updated

docs.title: Authentication
docs.text:
Manage your authentication using the steev auth command.

steev auth <subcommand>

This command allows you to authenticate your Steev account. You can sign in or log in using this command. During the beta phase, Steev is completely free. However, authentication is required because the LLM Agent needs to analyze your logs to provide optimal service.

docs.title: login
docs.text:
steev auth login

Use this command to log in or sign up for your Steev account. You have two login methods to choose from:

  1. Open a web browser
  2. Use the CLI

Expected output

# Login prompt
Choose authentication method:
> Log in with web browser (Login from local)
  Paste an auth token (Login from remote server)

If you are using a remote server, you can log in by pasting an auth token. steev uses Google OAuth for authentication.

Once you log in, your token will be saved in the ~/.steev/credentials.json file.

Expected output

example of credentials.json file: 

{
  "user": "username", 
  "email": "steev@steev.io", 
  "token": {
    "access_token": "some access token",
    "refresh_token": "some refresh token",
    "access_exp": 1738657951 # access token expiration time in integer
  }
}

docs.title: status
docs.text:
You can check your credentials using the status subcommand.

steev auth status

Expected output

Credential
  user   
  email  steev@steev.io
tokens
  access_token   some access token...
  refresh_token  some refresh token...
  access_exp     2099-12-25 23:59:59

docs.title: logout
docs.text:
You can log out using the logout subcommand.

steev auth logout

Expected output

Successfully logged out

This commands revoke your access token and refresh token. and delete the ~/.steev/credentials.json file.

docs.title: verify
docs.text:
You can verify your credentials using the verify subcommand.

steev auth verify

If the credentials are valid, you will see the following output:

Expected output

Credential token is valid

If the credentials are invalid, you will see the following output:

Expected output

Credential token is invalid

docs.title: refresh
docs.text:
You can refresh your credentials using the refresh subcommand.

steev auth refresh

Expected output

Credential token refreshed

This commands refresh your access token and refresh token. and update the ~/.steev/credentials.json file.

docs.title: Run Experiments
docs.text: Execute your training code using the steev run command. Steev will automatically run your experiment code and analyze the results.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
steev run TRAIN_FILE [OPTIONS]

steev analyzes your experiment code, generates an executable script, and executes it for you. This eliminates the need to write additional scripts or code to run experiments.

Warning

The current version of steev only supports the transformers and unsloth libraries.

docs.title: Arguments:
docs.text:
• TRAIN_FILE: Path to the training file.
  • --steev-cfg PATH: Path to your Steev configuration file. Default is steev.cfg. For more details, see Steev Config.
  • --kwargs "KWARG1=VAL1,KWARG2=VAL2": Keyword arguments for training. For more details, see Keyword Arguments (kwargs).

docs.title: Examples:
docs.text:
steev run train.py
steev run train.py --steev-cfg steev.cfg
steev run train.py --kwargs epoch=10,lr=0.001,batch_size=32
steev run train.py --kwargs "epoch=10 lr=0.001 batch_size=32"

Note

When using spaces in kwargs, enclose them in quotes. Without quotes, use commas without spaces between each kwarg. Remember there is no space between the key and the value when you use commas to separate kwargs. 

steev run train.py --kwargs epoch=10,lr=0.001
steev run train.py --kwargs "epoch=10 lr=0.001"

docs.title: Keyword Arguments (kwargs)
docs.text:
Pass keyword arguments to the execution. For example, to set the learning rate to 0.001 and epoch to 10, use:

steev run train.py --kwargs "epoch=10 lr=0.001"

Editing train.py to accept kwargs is not required. You can pass kwargs as you usually do.

During training, if Steev detects anomalies in experiment logs, it will send you an email notification. You can abort the experiment by pressing the Abort Experiment button in the email, and Steev will stop the experiment.
